history.content:
Yeah, 127 isn't well run. Personally, I don't think the lectures go over the important parts of the material, and the discussion worksheets and homework problems seem to just require unrelated tricks. Supposedly the principles and "tricks" behind convex optimization are deeply rooted in linear algebra but I'm not really seeing it. It's definitely a hard class to teach, but the staff don't seem that committed. 126 is well run like 61AB/70/170. 127 is more run like 61C in its bad semesters. The textbook (as well as the Boyd book) goes more in depth but it's pretty dense. There's an online Livebook that El Ghaoui though made which is pretty good so that'll probably be your best resource.

-----

"Ergonomics" guy here. Agree with the above answer. A disturbing trend in the class is the tendency for homework problems to use some special linear algebra "trick" that most students have never heard of. The TAs will tell folks in office hours, and it will trickle down via their friends but not very well (imagine messed-up LaTeX telephone). So everyone is agonizing over a single problem for hours until 24 hours before the deadline when Prof. el Ghaoui releases the hint on a bCourses announcement. 

Perhaps Prof. Bayen may be a better lecturer, he has great reviews on RMP. I'm not sure how much the GSIs (not uGSIs!) can improve at teaching because a) a lot of this material is easy for them as they're grad students at Berkeley, and b) they aren't particularly incentivized to spend a lot of time teaching instead of doing research, because, well, they're grad students at Berkeley and teaching isn't their primary job.

I think the material is super super interesting (not just for ML!) and if you're able to devote a lot of time to the class you'll get a lot out of it. But it can be frustrating to not have the same "structure" that 61A/B/70/170/126 gives you.

Hey referring to the discussion in post @6141 is EECS127 really badly run? Although I understand that the course teaches a lot of important aspects of optimization but I feel if the course is not run well and if resources are scarce it really limits my ability to understand the material. I have heard a lot of good things about EECS126's course staff and the material, does the same not hold for EECS127? Are there future plans to improve the class?
history.subject: EECS127 Ergonomics
